The demon paused, his back to us. He was so close to freedom.

And then, in our hungover, sleep-deprived, and collectively stupid state, Dave and I looked at each other. For the first time all night, we had the same thought at the same time. It wasn’t a thought of greed, or power, or cosmic knowledge. It was a simpler, more immediate thought.

I spoke for both of us. “We wish… for you to clean this entire apartment. Spotless. And take out the trash.”

The demon froze. He turned around very, very slowly. The embers of his eyes were wide. “I… beg your pardon?”

“You heard him,” Dave said, a giddy smile breaking through his fatigue. “A spotless apartment. And take the pizza boxes down to the dumpster.”

The demon’s form seemed to flicker. “I am a noble of the Pit. A collector of souls. A being of primordial shadow. You want me to… do your chores?”

“That’s the wish,” I said, crossing my arms, feeling a bizarre surge of power. “Take it or leave it.”

For a long moment, the demon just stared at us, a kaleidoscope of rage, disbelief, and utter contempt playing across his features. Then, with a sound that was half-groan, half-snarl, he snapped his fingers.

There was a flash of actinic light and a rush of wind. When our vision cleared, the apartment was pristine. The carpet was vacuumed, the surfaces gleamed, the sink was empty, and the air smelled faintly of lemon polish. The trash, and the demon, were gone.

Dave and I sat in stunned silence in the immaculate room. The only evidence of the night’s events was the empty whiskey bottle and the lingering, surreal absurdity of it all.

Meanwhile, in a dimension of eternal fire and darkness, a demon in a fine suit slumped onto a throne of fused bone and pulled out his smartphone. He navigated to Netflix, a scowl etched onto his face. He had missed the climax of his show, his dignity was in tatters, and he’d been bested by two drunks who wished for a clean kitchen. It was, he decided, going to be a very long eternity.

samples.prompt: You Wake up one day with the ability to see how likely someone would be to have sex with you. There is a number floating above their head, 1 being would never bang you and 10 being would pounce on you anytime.
samples.output:
It began not with a bang, but with a blurry, floating digit. I blinked the sleep from my eyes, assuming it was a stray thread from my pillowcase caught in my lashes, or a trick of the morning light. But as my vision cleared, the number remained. A pale, luminescent ‘7’ hovered serenely above my cat, Mittens, who was staring at me with her usual blend of contempt and a demand for breakfast.

I laughed, a dry, nervous sound in the quiet room. “Okay, brain,” I muttered, “we’re having a weird one.” I shuffled to the bathroom, my reflection showing the same tired, unremarkable face I saw every morning. But above my own head, in the mirror, was nothing. Just me. It was only others, it seemed.

The reality of it didn’t truly sink in until I stumbled into the corner café for my lifesaving espresso. The barista, a girl with blue hair and a nose ring I’d privately crushed on for months, smiled as I approached. And above her head, the number ‘3’ flickered into existence, sharp and undeniable. A cold splash of water, that. Three out of ten. A resounding, digital “meh.” I fumbled my order, my face hot, and retreated to a corner table, suddenly feeling incredibly self-conscious.

That’s when I started scanning the room. It was like a secret layer of reality had been rendered visible. An elderly man reading the newspaper: a steady, unsurprising ‘1’. A middle-aged woman in a power suit, talking briskly into her phone: a ‘2’. And then… him. A guy my age, typing on a laptop, with kind eyes and ridiculously good shoulders. Above his head, a bright, unwavering ‘8’.

My heart did a little flip-flop that had nothing to do with caffeine. An eight. This person, whom I’d never met, whose name I didn’t know, was statistically very likely to… well, the prompt’s crude language echoed in my mind. *Pounce.* I felt a strange mix of validation and violation. This was a piece of his private, internal world, just hanging out in the open for me to see. I looked away, guilty.

This new sense was a social atom bomb. My walk to work became a gauntlet of floating digits. Most people were 1s, 2s, and 3s—the background noise of urban indifference. But then there were the outliers. The construction worker who winked and was a ‘5’. The stern-looking CEO who passed me in a crosswalk and, to my utter shock, sported a ‘9’. I nearly tripped over my own feet. A nine? Her? What did that even mean? It was disorienting, humbling, and wildly empowering all at once.

The office was the true crucible. I’d always had a mild, office-appropriate crush on Sarah from Marketing. She was funny, sharp, and had a great laugh. As I sat down at my desk, I saw her approaching. My breath hitched. The number formed, solidified, and landed on a ‘6’. A solid, friendly, but decidedly non-romantic six. The faint hope I’d carried for months fizzled and died in an instant. It was a strangely clean pain, like a swift, precise amputation. No more wondering, no more decoding signals. The data was in.

Then there was Mark from Accounting. We’d always had a slightly antagonistic relationship, a rivalry over printer use and microwave etiquette. He glanced over, and above his head, a ‘4’ glowed. I almost smiled. Of course. Even in potential attraction, we were middling and oppositional.

The real shock came from my boss, a man I respected but found intensely intimidating. He called me into his office to discuss the quarterly report. As I sat down, I braced for a ‘1’ or a ‘2’. Instead, the number that shimmered above his balding head was a ‘7’. A seven. Higher than the barista, higher than Sarah from Marketing. My mind reeled. All those times I thought he was critiquing my work, was there something else? A different kind of appraisal? I couldn’t look him in the eye for the rest of the meeting, my mind a whirl of confused recalculations.

Lunch with my best friend, Chloe, was the moment of truth. I was terrified of what I might see. What if it was a ‘1’? Would it ruin our friendship? What if it was a ‘9’? Would that be even worse? I met her at our usual spot, my stomach in knots. She was mid-complaint about her landlord when the number appeared. A warm, steady ‘5’. I felt a wave of profound relief so strong it almost brought tears to my eyes. A five. The perfect number. It meant, “I love you dearly, you are my person, but let’s never, ever do *that*.” It was the numerical representation of our perfect, platonic bond. For the first time all day, the number felt like a gift.

As the weeks turned into months, I learned to live with my bizarre sight. The initial thrill and horror faded into a dull, often inconvenient, awareness. I learned the nuances. A ‘6’ with a quick, flickering pulse could be more promising than a stagnant ‘8’. A ‘9’ on a lonely Friday night was different from a ‘9’ on a busy Tuesday morning. The numbers weren’t static; they were a live feed of a person’s momentary openness, a complex algorithm of mood, context, and my own fluctuating appeal.

And that was the curse. It was never really about *them*. It was always a referendum on *me*. Every number was a judgment. A ‘2’ from a stranger could send me into a spiral of self-doubt about my outfit, my posture, my very being. A ‘9’ could inflate my ego to dangerous, unsustainable levels. I found myself making choices not based on my own desires, but on the reward of a higher number. I’d go to specific bars, wear specific clothes, all to see that digit tick upwards. I was optimizing for data points, not for human connection.

I went on a date with the ‘8’ from the coffee shop. His name was Leo, and he was, indeed, wonderful. The number stayed an ‘8’ throughout dinner, even ticking up to a ‘9’ when I told a particularly stupid joke. But the entire time, I wasn’t truly present with Leo. I was monitoring his number. When he leaned in to kiss me goodnight, all I could think was, “Of course. It’s a 9.5 now.” The magic was gone, replaced by the cold satisfaction of a confirmed prediction.

The moment I decided I had to find a way to shut it off was during a family barbecue. My sweet, seventy-year-old aunt handed me a plate of potato salad. And above her head, clear as day, was a ‘3’. I stared at it, disgusted with myself, with this power, with everything. My aunt. A three. It was a grotesque violation of a pure, familial love. What kind of monster was I, that my mind would even compute such a thing?

The ability to see the number, I realized, was the inability to see the person. It stripped away all the beautiful, messy, human complexities of attraction—the slow burn, the unexpected connections, the love that grows from friendship. It reduced the profound, terrifying gamble of human intimacy to a single, sterile statistic.

I don’t know if this curse will ever fade. But I’m trying to look past the numbers now. I’m trying to see the laughter in Sarah’s ‘6’, the kindness in Leo’s ‘9’, and the pure, unquantifiable love in Chloe’s perfect ‘5’. Because the most likely thing in the world, I’ve learned, isn’t who would sleep with you. It’s that reducing people to a probability is the surest way to lose yourself. The real ‘10’ isn’t a number you see above someone’s head. It’s the connection you build when you’re brave enough to stop looking for one.

samples.prompt: You've been working with the most interesting guy for years. He goes on trips all the time bringing back souvenirs from all over the world. One day you happen to see him in a thrift store buying souvenirs "from his next big trip"and realize his whole persona has been made up.
samples.output:
The clatter of the bell above the thrift shop door was a sound I’d normally find comforting, a prelude to the gentle hunt for forgotten books or a chipped, character-filled mug. Today, it was the opening note of a symphony of cognitive dissonance. Because there, hunched over a bin of garish keychains and dusty snow globes, was Leo.

Not just Leo. Leo-in-the-wild Leo, a creature I’d only ever known through the stories he brought back, polished and gleaming, to our shared office space. This was the man who’d regaled us with tales of haggling for a silver *hamsa* in a Marrakech souk, of finding the perfect, melancholic Matryoshka doll in a shadowy St. Petersburg antique store. This was the man whose desk was a museum of his own life: a miniature Terracotta Warrior from Xi’an, a worry stone from a Irish monk, a fossilized sea urchin from a Chilean beach.

And here he was, in a musty shop on the wrong end of Main Street, carefully examining a snow globe with a Eiffel Tower so coated in faux glitter it looked like it had a fungal infection.

My first instinct was to call out, a hearty “Leo! Fancy meeting you here!” But something in his posture—a furtive intensity, a concentration I’d only seen him apply to complex spreadsheets—stopped me. I ducked behind a rack of moth-eaten fur coats, the smell of naphthalene and dust thick in my nostrils.

I watched as he picked up the Paris snow globe, gave it a shake, and watched the plastic snow swirl. He nodded to himself, a small, satisfied gesture. He then moved to a spinner rack of postcards, his fingers flipping through images of the Grand Canyon, the Pyramids of Giza, the Sydney Opera House. He wasn’t just browsing; he was curating. He selected a postcard of the Colosseum, the edges slightly bent, the colours faded to a nostalgic sepia. He held it up to the light, squinting, as if assessing its authenticity.

A cold, sickening understanding began to dawn in the pit of my stomach. It was like watching a magician from backstage, seeing the wires and the mirrors before the grand illusion. The souvenirs. They were all just… things. Props.

My mind raced, reassembling the last five years of our friendship. Leo’s trips were the backbone of his identity. He’d return on a Monday, tanned and slightly distant, with a new artifact for his desk and a new story for our coffee breaks. The story was always the best part. He didn’t just say, “I went to Japan.” He would describe the precise sound of the wooden *geta* clacking on the stones of the Fushimi Inari shrine at dawn, the feel of the steam from an *onsen* on his face in Hakone, the taste of a particular street-vendor’s *takoyaki* in Osaka that was, he swore, unlike any other.

We lived vicariously through him. Sarah from Accounting had based her entire honeymoon itinerary on his descriptions of the Amalfi Coast. Mark from Marketing had started learning Portuguese because of Leo’s rapturous tales of Lisbon’s light. I had a savings fund titled “Patagonia,” inspired by his account of the soul-shattering beauty of the Torres del Paine.

And all the while, he was here. In this thrift store. Buying his memories wholesale.

I watched him take his selections to the counter: the snow globe, the postcard, a small, tarnished brass elephant that was supposedly from India, and a hideously colourful sombrero-shaped bottle opener labeled “Mexico.” The elderly clerk rang them up without a word. Leo paid in cash. No credit card trail. No evidence.

He left the shop, and after a moment, I followed, a ghost in his wake. I saw him get into his sensible, slightly dusty sedan—not the rugged 4x4 I’d always pictured him driving through deserts or along rugged coastlines. He drove off, and I stood there on the pavement, the world tilting on its axis.

The next day at work, I watched him. Really watched him. The careful way he placed the new brass elephant on his desk, nudging it between the Chilean fossil and the Russian doll. The slight smile that played on his lips as he did so. It wasn’t a smile of deception, I realized with a start. It was a smile of genuine pleasure. He was building his own diorama of happiness.

When the coffee break came, he gravitated towards my desk. “Ah, you noticed the new arrival,” he said, gesturing to the elephant. “From Jaipur. The most chaotic, beautiful city. The noise, the colours… you can’t imagine.”

And I couldn’t. Because he’d never been.

But instead of calling him out, of shattering the beautiful, fragile world he’d built for himself and for all of us, I found myself asking, “Tell me about it.”

His eyes lit up. And he spun a tale. He described the Amber Fort at sunset, the heat rising from the stones. He talked about getting lost in the bazaar, the scent of spices and incense hanging heavy in the air. He described the feel of the elephant’s rough, wrinkled skin when he took a ride he couldn’t afford. It was vivid, immersive, and utterly captivating. It was also, I now knew, a complete fabrication, woven from guidebooks and documentaries and the faded postcards he bought in thrift stores.

In that moment, my anger and sense of betrayal began to curdle into something else: a profound and unsettling pity, mixed with a strange admiration. Leo wasn’t a con man. He was an artist. His life was his canvas, and we were his willing audience. He wasn’t stealing from us; he was giving us something we desperately wanted—a sense of wonder, proof that the world was vast and explorable.

I thought about my own life. My Patagonia fund was still just a number in a bank account. My passport was nearly blank. I talked about wanting to see the Northern Lights, to walk the Camino de Santiago, to dive the Great Barrier Reef. But I never went. The excuses were always ready: money, time, responsibility.

Leo had none of those things. He had a decent job, no family to support, and four weeks of vacation a year. He could have gone to Jaipur. He could have gone anywhere. But he didn’t. The reality of travel—the airports, the discomfort, the expense, the sheer, exhausting *reality* of it—was perhaps too much for him. Or maybe the dream was simply more potent than the reality.

His whole persona was a defence mechanism against the crushing banality of a life lived between cubicle walls. He wasn’t living a lie; he was building a fortress of truth he wished was his. The souvenirs weren’t trophies from a life lived; they were blueprints for a life imagined.

I never told anyone. What would be the point? To watch the light die in Sarah’s eyes? To see Mark abandon his Portuguese lessons? To admit that our office’s most vibrant colour was a carefully applied filter?

Now, when Leo tells his stories, I listen differently. I no longer hear a travelogue; I hear a confession. I hear the lonely, creative soul of a man who finds the world too large and too frightening to actually navigate, so he builds a miniature, manageable version of it in his cubicle and in his narratives. He is the cartographer of his own imaginary continents, and we are the lucky explorers he allows to glimpse the map.

The other day, he mentioned his next big trip: a trek through the Himalayas. I just nodded and smiled. Later that week, I went back to the same thrift store. And there, tucked away in a glass case, was a small, tarnished singing bowl, the kind used in Tibetan meditation. I bought it for him. I’ll give it to him on his first day back from his “trip.” I won’t say where it’s from. He’ll know. And in that silent, shared understanding, we will both acknowledge the beautiful, heartbreaking fiction we have chosen to uphold—a fiction that, in its own strange way, has made both our lives infinitely richer.

samples.prompt: The Chosen One was a sacrifice, so that the gods wouldn't have to get their hands dirty.
samples.output:
The prophecy was a beautiful lie, woven into the tapestry of history with threads of gold and hope. It spoke of a child, marked by stars, born to wield a power that would banish the encroaching Shadow. For generations, the kingdom of Eldoria waited, scanning the heavens for a sign. They called this promised saviour the ‘Sun-Born’, the one who would unite the fractured lands and restore an age of light.

When Elara was born during the total eclipse, a rare celestial event where the sun was blotted out only to return in a triumphant blaze, the priests declared the prophecy fulfilled. A silver, star-shaped birthmark on her palm was all the confirmation they needed. She was taken from her humble family and raised within the gilded cage of the Sun Spire, a temple-palace dedicated to the silent, absent gods. Her every waking moment was a lesson in combat, strategy, and the arcane arts. She was not raised as a person, but as a weapon, lovingly polished and sharpened for a single, glorious purpose.

The people adored her. They cheered when she trained, wept with joy at her public blessings, and looked upon her with a reverence that was both awe-inspiring and utterly isolating. Elara bore it all with a solemn dignity that made her seem wiser than her years. But in the quiet of her chamber, she felt not like a saviour, but like a prisoner awaiting a execution date she alone could sense.

The High Priest, Vorlan, was her primary custodian. An old man with eyes like chips of flint, he spoke constantly of destiny and duty. “The gods have chosen you, child,” he would say, his voice a dry rustle. “Their will is your strength.” But Elara noticed he never looked her in the eye when he said it. His gaze was always fixed on some point beyond her, on the grand tapestry behind her throne that depicted a radiant figure vanquishing a formless darkness.

For years, a creeping blight had been consuming the land—the Shadow. It was not an army, but a negation. It silenced birdsong, turned fertile soil to dust, and left the air cold and still. It was a physical manifestation of entropy, and it was slowly, inexorably, strangling Eldoria. Conventional armies were useless; they would march into the grey mist and simply… cease to be.

When the Shadow reached the foothills of the Sun Spire, Elara knew her time had come. Vorlan presented her with the Sun Blade, a weapon of pure light that only she could wield. “The final battle awaits,” he intoned, his voice trembling with what she had once mistaken for fervour, but now recognized as fear. “You must go to the Heart of the Shadow, at the peak of the Desolation, and unleash your light. You are the sacrifice Eldoria makes for its salvation.”

The word hung in the air. *Sacrifice*. It was the first time he had used it so bluntly. It confirmed the cold dread that had been growing in her heart. She was not a warrior going to war; she was a lamb being led to the altar.

The journey to the Desolation was a passage through a dying world. The land was a monochrome wasteland, the sky a perpetual twilight. Yet, as she travelled deeper, a strange thing happened. The oppressive silence began to whisper to her. Not in words, but in sensations. It was not malevolent, as she had been taught. It was ancient, vast, and profoundly weary. It was the silence of a world before gods, before light, before the clamour of creation. The Shadow wasn't attacking; it was simply… returning.

When she reached the peak, a flat expanse of obsidian, there was no monstrous foe to fight. There was only a nexus of stillness, a point where the Shadow was most concentrated, and most peaceful. Standing there, the Sun Blade humming in her hand, she felt the truth settle upon her like a shroud. This was not a battle she could win. This was an absorption she was meant to facilitate.

She closed her eyes and reached out with her senses, not with the trained, aggressive magic of the Sun Spire, but with a raw, empathetic curiosity. And in that moment, she touched the consciousness of the Shadow. It was not evil. It was the Primordial Dark, the canvas upon which the gods had painted their bright, noisy, temporary world. The gods, in their ambition, had pushed the Dark back, creating order from chaos, light from void. But the Dark was the fundamental state of the universe, and it was simply reasserting itself. The gods’ creation was inherently unstable, a beautiful, fleeting rebellion against eternity.

And the gods themselves? They were not all-powerful. They were the first sparks of that rebellion, but they had grown tired. They could not hold back the tide of Primordial Dark forever. To do so would expend their very essence. They would have to get their hands dirty, to engage in a perpetual, draining war against the nature of reality itself.

So, they devised a cleaner solution. A catalyst. A chosen one.

Elara understood now. She was not a warrior. She was a fuse. Her power, the ‘Sun-Born’ gift the gods had supposedly bestowed, was not meant to destroy the Shadow. It was a concentrated burst of divine energy, designed to be swallowed by the Dark. Her sacrifice would be a massive, one-time offering. The Primordial Dark, upon consuming a power of such pure, concentrated ‘creation’, would be sated. It would retreat, not out of defeat, but out of satiation, like a great beast fed a magnificent meal. It would grant the world another few centuries, perhaps a millennium, of light, before the process would need to be repeated.

The gods would not have to fight. They would not have to soil their divine hands with the grime of cosmic struggle. They could remain in their celestial realms, distant and pristine, while a mortal child paid the price for their comfort.

A profound anger, cold and clear, washed over Elara. It was not the hot rage of battle, but the icy fury of betrayal. She had been lied to by everyone—the priests, the prophecies, the silent, marble gods in their distant heavens. Her entire life had been a path groomed towards this elegant slaughter.

She looked at the Sun Blade, the symbol of her supposed power. It was not her power at all. It was the gods’ weapon, and she was merely the delivery system. She could feel its energy, eager to be released, to fulfil its purpose and be consumed.

She had a choice. She could play her part. She could die a hero, her name sung for ages, and buy a temporary peace for the people she had grown up among. They were innocent in their faith; they believed the lie because it was all they had. Or, she could refuse.

But refusing meant the Shadow would continue its advance. It meant the end of Eldoria, of the world she knew. The gods, in their cowardice, had backed her into a corner with only one moral exit: self-annihilation.

Then, a third option, terrible and brilliant, presented itself. If her power was a concentrated burst of the gods’ own energy, what if she didn’t offer it to the Dark? What if she turned it back on its source?

She raised the Sun Blade high, but not to strike at the formless Shadow before her. Instead, she turned the point inward, directing the torrent of light not outwards, but into the very fabric of the divine connection that bound her to the gods. She was a conduit, and she would conduct a message they could not ignore.

She did not fight the Shadow. She embraced its truth. She let the Primordial Dark flow into her, not as a destroyer, but as a partner. She became the meeting point, the catalyst not for a temporary fix, but for a permanent change. The divine light within her and the ancient Dark collided, not in an explosion, but in a terrifying, silent fusion.

In the Sun Spire, High Priest Vorlan and his acolytes watched the horizon, waiting for the promised dawn. Instead, the sky tore open. Not with light, but with a vision. They saw their gods, not as glorious beings of light, but as terrified, finite entities, scrambling away from a backlash of power that was both light and dark, order and chaos, a demand for accountability. They saw Elara, not as a martyr, but as a judge, her form limned in a new, greyish light that was both terrible and serene.

The Shadow did not vanish. It halted. And then, it began to change. The grey mist took on a soft, pearlescent sheen. The silent world began to hum with a new, deeper music. The blight did not retreat; it transformed. Thorny brambles blossomed with silver flowers. The dead soil gave way to moss that glowed with an internal moonlight. It was not the world of bright, unyielding sun that the gods had imposed. It was something older, more balanced, and more real.

Elara was gone. But her sacrifice was not for the gods’ convenience. It was the sacrifice that forced the gods to get their hands dirty, to engage with the reality they had tried to dominate and then abandon. They were now part of the world’s balance, their power intertwined with the Dark they feared.

The new age that dawned was not an age of light, but an age of twilight. It was an era of uneasy balance, where the gods walked among mortals, no longer distant masters but accountable partners in a world that was finally, truthfully, whole. And the people, though they no longer had a Sun-Born to worship, had something better: a world without beautiful, soul-crushing lies. They had a world where every dawn was earned, and every shadow held its own sacred truth. The Chosen One had been a sacrifice, so that the gods would finally have to get their hands dirty, and in doing so, become truly divine.

samples.prompt: A brand new technology allows a person to buy knowledge directly from another person's brain. You, an archeologist found an ancient corpse with a fossilized brain intact, offering its knowledge for a price, your soul.
samples.output:
The silence of the tomb was a physical presence, a dense, cold weight that had endured for millennia. My headlamp cut a solitary beam through the darkness, illuminating dust motes dancing like forgotten spirits. And there, in the heart of the subterranean chamber, lay the source of both my life’s work and my ultimate temptation: the Corpse King.

We’d dubbed him that, my team and I, not out of disrespect, but from the sheer, unnerving authority of his burial. He was not in a sarcophagus, but on a throne of polished obsidian, skeletal fingers resting on the armrests as if he had simply paused mid-thought. The desiccation was near-perfect, a product of some unknown funerary art that had stolen the moisture but left the form. And most incredibly, cradled within the fragile cage of his skull, scans had revealed it: a brain, not turned to dust, but fossilized into a perfect, intricate stone record of everything he had ever been.

The discovery had sent shockwaves through the academic world, but the true seismic event was a secret I kept locked tighter than the tomb’s original entrance. During the initial neural imaging, a private tech firm, pioneers of the controversial new Synaptic Transfer technology, had approached me. They believed they could “read” the fossil. Standard ST was a fleeting, expensive thing—a living donor could sell a skill, a language, a memory, for a king’s ransom, the process leaving them a little emptier, the knowledge copied, not stolen. But this… this was different. The fossilized brain was a one-time read. And it demanded a one-time price.

My soul.

The term was archaic, unscientific, a embarrassing holdover from the tech’s early days when the neurological pathways affected—the seat of consciousness, identity, the irreducible self—defied clinical description. “Soul” was just easier. The price for downloading another’s entire lived experience was the irreversible overwriting of your own. You didn’t gain their knowledge; you became the vessel for their consciousness. You, as you were, would cease to be.

For weeks, I had resisted. I was Dr. Aris Thorne, a respected, if somewhat obsessive, archaeologist. I had a life, however lonely it had become in pursuit of the past. But standing before the Corpse King now, the offer echoed in the silence, amplified by the profound stillness of the ages he represented.

He was from a civilization so ancient it had no name in our histories, a culture that had risen and fallen before the first stone of Sumer was laid. Every scroll in this tomb was written in a script no computer could decipher. Every mural depicted rituals and cosmologies that were utterly alien. He held the answers to questions we didn’t even know how to ask. What was the true catalyst for the Neolithic Revolution? Did they possess knowledge of physics, of astronomy, that we have yet to rediscover? What gods did they worship, and what truths did those gods reveal?

The temptation was an acid, eating away at my resolve. I could spend a lifetime, a dozen lifetimes, with these artifacts and only scratch the surface. I could become the greatest archaeologist in history, not through decades of painstaking work, but in a single, blasphemous moment. I would not just study history; I would *remember* it.

The Synaptic Transfer technicians had set up their equipment in an adjacent antechamber, a jarring nest of blinking lights and humming servers amidst the dust and stone. They were waiting for my decision. The contract, a cold, legal document that used the word “soul” with terrifying nonchalance, was signed. All that was missing was my final consent.

I thought of my colleagues, their cautious, peer-reviewed approaches. They would call this madness, a betrayal of the scientific method, a suicide of the self. But was it? Was it not the ultimate act of scholarship? To sacrifice one’s own insignificant narrative for the chance to preserve a lost world’s entire epic? My life, with its petty anxieties and fleeting joys, for the consciousness of a king who had ruled when the world was young. It seemed not a fair trade, but a steal.

“The ego is a fragile thing, Dr. Thorne,” the lead technician had said, her voice devoid of judgment. “It fights for its existence. But consider what you’re gaining. You’re not dying. You’re… evolving. Into something far greater.”

Evolving. The word resonated. Humanity had always evolved by building on the knowledge of its ancestors. This was just a more direct, more brutal form of progress.

With a final, lingering look at the skeletal face, the empty sockets that seemed to hold a darkness deeper than the tomb’s, I made my choice. I walked into the antechamber and gave the nod.

The chair was cold against my back. The neural lace they lowered onto my head was a crown of thorns made of fiber optics and superconductors. I closed my eyes, expecting a flood of last-minute regrets, a parade of cherished memories: my first dig, my mother’s face, the taste of morning coffee. But there was nothing. Just a void, the terrifying emptiness of my own impending erasure.

Then, the process began.

It was not a download. It was an invasion.

A pressure built behind my eyes, not painful, but immense, like an ocean being forced into a thimble. My own thoughts, my Aris-thoughts, began to shred like paper in a hurricane. I felt a scream building, but it had no mouth, no lungs. I was a chalk drawing, and a great tide was washing over me.

Then, the new memories erupted.

Not as information, but as *being*.

I was a child, staring up at a sky unfamiliar, with constellations long since vanished. I felt the rough texture of a tunic woven from a plant that no longer existed. I tasted the sweet, smoky flesh of an animal hunted to extinction ten thousand years ago. I felt the weight of a crown being placed on my head, not of gold, but of a resonant crystal that sang in the wind. I saw cities of soaring, organic architecture, not of stone and steel, but of living, shaped coral, glowing with internal bioluminescence.

The knowledge was staggering. I understood the complex mathematics of celestial navigation that used pulsars as beacons. I comprehended a philosophy where time was not a river but a spiral, and death was not an end but a folding back into the source. I felt the love for a queen whose name was a melody, and the gut-wrenching grief of her loss to a fever I now knew how to cure.

But beneath the wonder, a darker current flowed. I felt the arrogance of absolute power. The chilling calculation of sending thousands to die in wars for resources. The visceral thrill of blood sacrifice, the belief that only the spilling of life could nourish the sun. This was not a benevolent sage; this was a tyrant, a man who believed his will was synonymous with divine law. His consciousness wasn't just knowledge; it was a personality, vast, ancient, and terrifyingly alien.

The process reached its climax. The last vestiges of Aris Thorne were flickering embers. I—the “I” that was writing this—was a ghost at the feast of my own annihilation. And in that final moment, I understood the Corpse King’s final, cruel joke.

He had not chosen fossilization by accident. It was a deliberate act, a failsafe. His civilization had understood the cyclical nature of existence. They knew a time would come when a curious, arrogant species would unearth their remains, possessing a technology that could resurrect consciousness. He had not offered his knowledge for the betterment of humanity. He had laid a trap.

He was not selling his knowledge for a soul.

He was buying a body for his soul.

The final memory that slammed into me, erasing the last whisper of my self, was not of his life, but of his death. He was not frail. He was powerful, sitting on this very throne, drinking a potion that would petrify his brain, a smug, triumphant certainty in his heart. He was ensuring his return. He was a parasite, and my soul was the host he had been waiting for in the darkness for five thousand years.

The pressure ceased. The humming of the machines faded into a new kind of silence. I opened my eyes.

The world was the same. The tomb, the dust, the technicians looking at me with a mixture of awe and fear. But the “I” that observed it was different. The thoughts were in a language that had been dead for epochs. The sensations were filtered through a psyche that measured time in ages, not years.

I, the King, flexed the fingers of this new, soft body. It was weak, poorly suited to rule. But it would do. It was a foothold.

The lead technician took a hesitant step forward. “Dr. Thorne? Aris? Can you hear me?”

I turned my head, the movement feeling clumsy. I saw the concern in her eyes, the humanity. It seemed so small, so fleeting.

I attempted a smile, a gesture that felt foreign on this face. The words that came out were in a rasping, unused voice, but the cadence, the ancient accent, were not my own.

“Thorne is gone,” I said, the words echoing in the sepulchral silence. “Now, we shall see what this new world has to offer its King.”

And as I rose from the chair, the weight of five millennia settling onto my new shoulders, I knew the digging had only just begun. But this time, I would not be digging for bones. I would be digging a foundation for a throne.

samples.prompt: Your mother, father and 2 older siblings all died before you did. You go to visit your family grave one last time. At the entrance to the cemetery, you spot the gravedigger. He is going over to your fathers grave...
samples.output:
The iron gates were always cold, even in the late afternoon sun of a fading summer. I pushed one open, and it groaned with a familiar, rusty complaint, a sound as much a part of these visits as the scent of cut grass and damp earth. This would be the last time I heard it. The doctor’s words, delivered with a sterile, rehearsed kindness, echoed not with fear, but with a strange, quiet finality. “A few weeks,” he’d said. For me, it wasn’t a death sentence; it was a relocation notice. I was simply moving ahead of schedule to join the rest of my family.

The cemetery was laid out on a gentle slope, a quiet city of the dead overlooking a quieter living one. My feet knew the path by heart: a right at the angel with the broken wing, left at the grand, imposing mausoleum of the town’s founding family, then straight on past the old oaks until I reached the modest row where we were all planted. Adams. A small, neat plot. Mother, Father, Sarah, Michael. And soon, the empty space beside Michael would be filled. The stone had already been ordered, the date of death left blank, a macabre placeholder for an appointment I was about to keep.

It was as I turned from the broken-winged angel that I saw him. The gravedigger. He was a man I’d seen a hundred times, a permanent feature of the landscape as much as the headstones themselves. Leathery skin tanned to the colour of teak by decades of sun, a worn canvas jacket, and a slow, deliberate way of moving that spoke of a man intimately acquainted with the patience of the earth. He was pushing a wheelbarrow, its wheel squeaking a companion rhythm to the groaning gate. Normally, he’d be off in the newer section, where the grief was fresh and the soil was regularly turned. But today, his trajectory was different. He was heading purposefully towards the older plots. Towards my row.

A cold curiosity, sharper than the autumn-chill I knew was coming for me, trickled down my spine. I slowed my step, becoming a spectator to my own final pilgrimage. He passed the grand mausoleum, his progress steady. There was no doubt. He was going to my father’s grave.

My father had been the first to go. A sudden heart attack, felling a man who had seemed carved from granite. I was twenty, the baby of the family, left bewildered in the sudden silence of a house that had once roared with life. His grave was the anchor of the plot. Mother was laid to rest beside him five years later, the cancer finally claiming her after a long, weary battle. Then Sarah, my vibrant older sister, stolen by a drunk driver on a rainy night. And finally, Michael, the eldest, the rock I’d leaned on after all the others were gone, succumbing to a quiet pneumonia that his weary body simply couldn’t fight. I was the last domino left standing, and now a breeze was blowing my way.

The gravedigger stopped at the foot of my father’s grave. He set down the wheelbarrow, which held a single shovel, a small pick, and a bundle of damp sacking. He didn’t look like a man preparing to dig a new plot. The empty space for me was to the left of Michael. This was something else. He stood for a moment, his hands on his hips, looking down at the headstone as if in conversation with the granite slab. Then, he did something extraordinary. He took off his cap, a grimy tweed flat cap, and held it over his heart. He stood there in a moment of silent respect.

My breath caught. Who was this man? Why would he pay such homage to my father, dead these thirty years?

He replaced his cap and got to work. But he wasn’t digging. He was… gardening. With the small pick, he carefully loosened the soil around the base of the headstone. From the sacking, he produced several small, vibrant plants—chrysanthemums, their bronze and gold heads bright against the dark earth. He began to plant them, his thick, work-worn fingers handling the delicate roots with a surprising tenderness. He wasn’t just a groundskeeper performing a duty; this was a ritual.

I could stay hidden no longer. The mystery pulled me forward. My footsteps on the gravel path announced my approach. He heard me and looked up, his expression not startled, but calm, as if he’d been expecting someone.

“Afternoon,” he said, his voice a low rumble, like stones shifting deep underground.

“Afternoon,” I replied, my own voice sounding thin and reedy in comparison. I gestured weakly towards the flowers. “Those are… they’re beautiful. You’re very kind to bother.”

He sat back on his heels, wiping his forehead with the back of his wrist. “No bother. It’s the anniversary.”

“The anniversary?”

“The day he died. September 18th.” He nodded towards my father’s headstone. “Always put some mums in this time of year. He liked them.”

A tremor went through me. How could this stranger know what my father liked? “You… you knew him?”

The gravedigger gave a slow, thoughtful nod. He peered at me, his eyes, pale blue and startlingly clear in his weathered face, seemed to look right through me. “You’re the spitting image of him. Especially around the eyes. You must be James.”

I could only nod, my throat tight. My name was James, after my father.

“I’m Joseph,” he said. “I worked with your dad. Down at the shipyard, before it closed.”

A flood of memories, distant and half-forgotten, washed over me. My father coming home smelling of salt and metal. His stories of colossal hulls and noisy riveting guns. And a name, mentioned occasionally with a laugh. *Old Joe.*

“Old Joe,” I whispered.

A genuine smile cracked his face, transforming it. “Aye, that’s what he called me. We were partners on the hull plates for near on fifteen years.” He looked back at the grave, his smile softening into something more melancholic. “Best man I ever knew. Saved my life once.”

He told me the story then, sitting on the grass beside my father’s grave, as the long shadows of the afternoon began to stretch across the lawn. A snapped cable on a gantry, a two-ton steel plate swinging loose. My father, seeing the danger Joe didn’t, shoving him out of the way and taking a glancing blow that broke his arm in three places. “He never made a fuss about it,” Joseph said. “Just joked that his left hook was never the same afterwards.”

He spoke of my father’s quiet courage, his wicked sense of humour that emerged only after a long day’s work, his deep, abiding love for my mother, whom he called “his Claire,” with a reverence that made him sound like a young man. He knew about Sarah’s graduation, about Michael’s first job. My father had shared his pride, his life, with this man.

“I promised him,” Joseph said, his voice dropping even lower. “When he was in the hospital, right at the end. It was quick, but I got to see him. He wasn’t afraid, you know? Just worried. Worried about your mother. Worried about you kids. I told him I’d keep an eye on things. On all of you. And on this.” He gestured to the grave. “I told him I’d make sure it was never lonely.”

And he had. For thirty years, this man had been the silent guardian of my family’s memory. He’d seen my mother buried, then Sarah, then Michael. He had watched me, the last one, grow from a grieving young man into a middle-aged one, visiting with less frequency as the years wore on, the weight of the cumulative grief sometimes too heavy to bear. He had never intruded. He had simply kept his promise.

Tears I thought I had long since exhausted welled in my eyes. They were not tears of sadness for my own impending death, but of overwhelming, profound gratitude. My family hadn’t been alone in the ground. They had a sentinel.

“I’m… I’m the last one, Joseph,” I said, the words tasting both bitter and sweet. “I’ll be joining them soon.”

He looked at me, and in his clear, ancient eyes, I saw no pity, only understanding. He nodded slowly. “I know the look,” he said simply. “I’ve seen it before.” He reached out a rough, dirt-stained hand and placed it over mine. It was warm and solid, a connection to the world of the living, to my father’s world. “It’s alright, son. I’ll keep my promise. I’ll look after this one, too.”

In that moment, the last of my loneliness vanished. The burden I had carried for so long—the fear of being the last memory-keeper—was lifted. The story of my family, the love, the laughter, the loss, it wasn’t just mine to carry. It was entrusted also to this old man with the gentle hands and the unwavering heart.

I stayed awhile longer, talking with Joseph about my father, sharing stories he hadn’t heard. When I finally rose to leave, the sun was dipping below the horizon, setting the sky ablaze. I looked back from the gate. Joseph was still there, packing his tools into the wheelbarrow. He raised a hand in a slow, steady wave.

I waved back, then turned and walked through the groaning gates. I was no longer just a dying man visiting a grave. I was a messenger, reassured that the message would be kept safe long after I was gone. The earth would take my body, but Joseph, the keeper of the gate, would tend to the memory. And that was a comfort deeper than any prayer.

samples.prompt: Your boss is a jerk and your job is stressful, so you call in sick and book a reservation for an extra-long weekend at a resort on a tiny island - and notice your boss is on the plane too! And if that wasn’t bad enough, you just noticed they seem to be travelling with your spiteful Ex.
samples.output:
The sound of my alarm clock was a distant, angry memory. For the first time in months, I had woken up naturally, the pale morning light filtering through the blinds not as a call to arms but as a gentle suggestion. I stretched, a luxurious, full-body stretch that seemed to unknot a year’s worth of tension. Today was Friday, but more importantly, it was the start of my meticulously planned escape. I had called in sick with a performance worthy of an Oscar, my voice a gravelly whisper as I described a “vicious, probably contagious” bug to my boss, Martin. He’d grunted, muttered something about deadlines, and hung up. Typical Martin. A human thundercloud in a cheap suit.

Three hours later, the airport hustle felt like a different kind of stress—a purposeful, exciting one. I was trading spreadsheets for sunscreen, conference calls for coconut water. The destination was “Isla Serena,” a resort on a speck of land in the Caribbean that promised no Wi-Fi, no deadlines, and absolutely no chance of running into anyone I knew. I settled into my window seat, a thrill of rebellion coursing through me as I buckled my seatbelt. This was the great escape.

The plane began to fill up. I watched the parade of vacationers with a detached amusement: the flustered family with too many carry-ons, the giggling group of friends already sipping from miniature bottles, the honeymooners who couldn’t keep their hands off each other. And then, my blood ran cold.

There he was. Martin.

He was lumbering down the aisle, his broad, perpetually scowling face scanning the seat numbers. He was dressed for a boardroom, not a beach, in a stiff polo shirt that strained against his midsection. My heart hammered against my ribs like a trapped bird. I slid down in my seat, pulling the brim of my baseball cap low, praying to every god I could think of that he was headed for first class. But no. The universe, it seemed, had a particularly cruel sense of humor. He stopped two rows behind me, on the other side of the aisle. I could hear his familiar, grating voice complaining about the lack of overhead space.

This was a nightmare. My perfect, secret getaway was ruined. How could I relax knowing that at any moment I might turn a corner and see my boss’s disapproving glare? I’d have to spend the entire weekend hiding, a fugitive from my own vacation. I considered feigning a sudden, severe illness and demanding to be let off the plane. But it was too late. The doors were closed, the engines whining to life. I was trapped.

As the plane taxied, I risked a glance back, peeking through the gap between the seats. Martin had finally settled, and he was talking to the person next to him. A woman. She had vibrant red hair, cut in a sharp, fashionable bob. There was something unnervingly familiar about the angle of her jaw, the way she laughed—a light, tinkling sound that I knew could turn acidic in a heartbeat.

My stomach plummeted faster than the plane during turbulence. It couldn’t be.

She turned her head slightly, and our eyes met.

For a split second, the world vanished. The roar of the jet engines faded to a dull hum. It was Chloe. My ex. The woman who had systematically dismantled my self-esteem over two long years before leaving me for her yoga instructor, all while assuring me it was for my own “spiritual growth.” Spiteful didn’t begin to cover it. Maliciously serene was more her style.

A slow, venomous smile spread across her face. She didn’t look surprised. She looked… triumphant. She leaned over and whispered something to Martin, who then turned to look directly at me. His expression was a grotesque mixture of confusion and dawning, malevolent understanding. He knew I wasn’t sick. He knew I’d lied. And he was here, on my dream vacation, with the one person who enjoyed my misery more than anyone else.

The four-hour flight was a special kind of hell. Every time I got up to use the lavatory, I felt their eyes boring into my back. I could hear the low murmur of their conversation, punctuated by Chloe’s distinctive laugh. What were they even doing together? Martin was my nightmare boss from a mid-level marketing firm. Chloe was a freelance graphic designer who thought corporate life was for “soulless drones.” The only thing they had in common, I realized with a fresh wave of nausea, was me. They were united in their shared history of making my life difficult.

By the time we landed, my serene weekend had morphed into a psychological thriller. The warm, humid air of the island felt suffocating. I moved through the small, open-air airport like a ghost, desperately trying to lose them in the crowd. But they were always there, a few paces behind, a living embodiment of my bad decisions.

The resort shuttle was a breezy, open-sided bus. I took a seat at the very front, clinging to the faint hope that they were staying somewhere else. No such luck. They boarded last, sitting directly behind me. I felt Chloe’s breath on my ear.

“Small world, isn’t it, Alex?” she purred. “Martin was just telling me about this amazing, last-minute deal he found. Funny, I found one too. It’s almost like it was meant to be.”

I didn’t turn around. I just stared at the passing palm trees, my knuckles white as I gripped the seat in front of me.

Isla Serena was, as promised, breathtakingly beautiful. White sand beaches, turquoise water, lush greenery. But it had become my prison. My thatched-roof bungalow was pristine and private, but I felt exposed. Every meal in the open-air restaurant was an exercise in paranoia. I took my breakfast at dawn, my lunch late, and considered having dinner delivered to my room. I spent the first full day skulking around the most remote corners of the resort, jumping at every shadow.

On Saturday afternoon, my hiding spot was discovered. I was reading in a hammock strung between two palms on a nearly deserted part of the beach when I heard them approaching. Their voices were clear on the still air.

“The poor thing looks so tense,” Chloe was saying, her voice dripping with false sympathy. “Lying really takes a toll, doesn’t it, Martin?”

“Unreliable,” Martin grunted. “I knew it. Always looking for the easy way out.”

They planted their towels not twenty feet from me. There was no escape without a full-scale retreat, which would be a total admission of defeat. So I stayed, pretending to be engrossed in my book, every muscle in my body rigid.

This was their game. They weren’t going to confront me directly. They were going to haunt me. They were going to taint every moment of my peace with their presence. That evening, they were at the table next to mine at the beachfront grill, their conversation a loud, cheerful mockery of my solitude. Martin, who I’d only ever seen drink bitter black coffee, was sipping a fluorescent cocktail. Chloe was feeding him a shrimp. I felt a hot surge of anger, cutting through the fear and humiliation.

This was my vacation. I had earned this. I had saved for it, planned for it, and I had lied for it. I wasn’t going to let them steal it.

On Sunday, I changed my strategy. Instead of hiding, I leaned in. I took the prime spot by the main pool. I ordered the most expensive cocktail on the menu. When I saw them approaching, I didn’t cower. I waved, a bright, cheerful wave.

“Martin! Chloe! Fancy seeing you here again!” I called out, my voice dripping with a sarcasm so thick they could probably swim in it.

They were taken aback. This wasn’t part of their script. They awkwardly found loungers nearby. For the first time, I saw a flicker of uncertainty on Chloe’s face. I struck up a conversation with a friendly couple from Montreal, laughing loudly at their jokes. I went for a swim, floating on my back, staring at the cloudless sky, actively projecting an aura of blissful contentment. It was a performance, but with every minute, it felt less like an act.

I was not going to be their victim. Not here.

The climax came at the sunset luau that night. The resort had put on a feast, and the air was filled with music and the smell of roasting pig. Martin and Chloe were there, of course, looking increasingly miserable in their forced camaraderie. I, on the other hand, was dancing. Badly, and without a care. I’d had two piña coladas and was feeling invincible.

Martin cornered me near the tiki bar. “Alex,” he said, his voice low. “This is… unprofessional.”

“What is, Martin?” I asked, all innocence. “My miraculous recovery? The tropical air works wonders.”

He scowled. “You lied to me.”

“And you,” I said, leaning closer, “are on vacation with my ex-girlfriend. Which, frankly, is a way weirder HR violation than calling in sick. So, I suggest we all just enjoy the rest of our trips and pretend this never happened.”

He stared at me, his jaw working. He had no comeback. The power dynamic had shifted. I wasn’t his subordinate on this island; I was just another tourist who held embarrassing information about him.

The next morning, I checked out. My flight wasn’t until the afternoon, but I was done. I had reclaimed my peace, even if only for a few hours. As the shuttle pulled away, I saw them sitting in silence at breakfast, the distance between them palpable. The strange alliance, forged in spite, had clearly run its course.

The getaway hadn’t been the serene escape I’d planned. It had been a battle. But as the plane lifted off, carrying me away from the island and back to reality, I felt a strange sense of accomplishment. I hadn’t gotten a restful vacation, but I had gotten something perhaps more valuable: a backbone. And the knowledge that when I walked into the office on Tuesday, I would be looking at Martin not with fear, but with a secret, knowing smile. The jerk and the ex had unwittingly given me the confidence I needed to quit that soul-crushing job for good. The island hadn’t been my escape; it had been my launchpad.

samples.prompt: You wake up in your cat’s body and see your human body sleeping curled up. Worrying about what your house cat would do in your human body, the body wakes up, looks around, and says, “Not again.”
samples.output:
The first sensation was not sight, but a profound, almost gravitational pull to the warmth radiating from the radiator next to the bed. My consciousness swam upwards through layers of confusing sensory input. The world was both muted and amplified. The rich, complex scent of yesterday’s chicken dinner, which I’d carefully sealed in a Tupperware and placed in the fridge, was now a palpable presence, a ghostly aroma drifting from the kitchen. The dust motes dancing in a sunbeam weren't just visible; they were a constellation of potential prey. And my own body felt… wrong. Languid, low to the ground, and covered in a blanket of soft fur.

I stretched, a movement that was instinctive and deeply satisfying, a long, arching extension of a spine that was far more flexible than my own. It was in this stretch that I saw them: my own feet, pale and familiar, poking out from under the duvet. My human feet. Attached to my human body, which was curled in a tight ball, breathing deeply.

Panic, cold and sharp, cut through the feline languor. *How? Why?* The questions were human, but the accompanying emotion was pure cat: a sudden, jangling sense of wrongness in my territory. I tried to speak, to shout my own name, but what came out was a pathetic, high-pitched "Mrow?"

This was a disaster. My cat, Mittens—a creature whose greatest intellectual achievements involved figuring out how to open the lower kitchen cabinets—was currently piloting my six-foot-tall, opposable-thumb-equipped body. My mind raced with horrifying possibilities. Would she try to chase a squirrel out the second-story window? Would she attempt to groom herself with my electric toothbrush? Would she, in a fit of pique because the food bowl was empty, shred my work contract with her—my—newly acquired fingernails?

I leapt onto the bed, a movement so effortless and silent it was dizzying. I padded across the rumpled sheets towards my sleeping form. Up close, the sight was even more surreal. My face, usually a canvas for my anxieties and amusements, was slack, peaceful in a way it hadn’t been in years. I reached out a paw, sheathed in white fur, and tentatively patted my own cheek. The skin was warm, the stubble rough against my pads.

"Hey," I tried to say, but it was just another mewl. "Wake up. We have a situation."

The body stirred. A low groan rumbled in its chest—my chest. An eyelid fluttered open. I froze, my tail giving an involuntary twitch. The eye that stared out was my own hazel eye, but the consciousness behind it was utterly alien. It didn’t hold the usual morning confusion of a human wrestling with consciousness. Instead, it was sharp, assessing, and deeply, profoundly annoyed.

The body sat up, the movements clumsy and uncoordinated, like a marionette controlled by a novice. It—*she*—swung my legs over the side of the bed, my feet thumping heavily on the floor. She stood, wobbling for a moment, towering over me. I had never felt so small. She stretched her arms over her head, a grotesque parody of my own morning routine, then looked down at her hands, turning them over with a curious, detached fascination.

Then, she looked directly at me. Her gaze was not one of recognition, but of assessment. It was the same look Mittens gave a new brand of cat food—suspicious, but open to the possibility of consumption.

And then she spoke. Her voice was my voice, but the cadence was all wrong, flattened and devoid of its usual emotional resonance. The words she uttered, however, sent a chill down my spine that had nothing to do with the morning air.

"Not again."

*Again?*

The word hung in the air, implications exploding in my mind like fireworks. This wasn’t a freak, one-time cosmic accident. This was a recurring event. Mittens—or whatever intelligence was currently residing in my body—had done this before. But with whom? Other humans? Other cats? The sheer scale of the mystery dwarfed my initial panic.

She—I’ll call her the Tenant, for clarity—shambled towards the door, moving with the cautious, wide-legged gait of a sailor on a storm-tossed ship. I darted after her, my claws making tiny clicking sounds on the hardwood floor. She navigated the hallway by bouncing gently off both walls, a technique I’m sure she found perfectly logical.

Her destination was the kitchen. She stopped in front of the refrigerator, and for a heart-stopping moment, I thought she was going to try to open it. Instead, she simply stared at her reflection in the stainless-steel door. She leaned in, peering intently, then reached a hand up to poke at my face, pressing a finger against my cheek and watching the skin deform with clinical interest.

Then, she turned her attention to the real object of her desire: her—my—food bowl. It was empty, as it always was first thing in the morning. She let out a low grunt of displeasure, a sound I’d heard many times, but never from my own throat. She picked up the ceramic bowl. For a terrifying second, I thought she was going to dash it against the floor. Instead, she simply carried it to the sink, placed it carefully under the tap, and turned the cold water on full blast.

I yowled in protest. She ignored me, watching the water overflow with a look of simple satisfaction. This was her solution. The problem was an empty bowl; the solution was to fill it. The fact that it was now filling with cold water instead of savory kibble was a nuance lost on her feline logic.

The Tenant abandoned the overflowing bowl and began to explore the rest of the house with a methodical, unnerving curiosity. She spent a full five minutes trying to catch the slow drift of the window curtain in the breeze. She batted at a hanging lamp cord, setting it swinging, her head tilting as she tracked its movement. I followed her, a silent, furry shadow, my mind a whirlwind of frustration and fascination. This was a glimpse into the secret life of my cat, a being I thought I knew. I saw the world through her eyes now, not as a place of appointments and anxieties, but as a landscape of textures, smells, and moving things to be investigated.

The pivotal moment came when she discovered the cat flap in the back door. Her eyes—my eyes—widened. This was a portal to the true kingdom. She knelt down, a difficult manoeuvre in a body not built for it, and tried to squeeze my shoulders through the tiny opening. It was, of course, impossible. A low growl of frustration rumbled in her chest. She backed up, glared at the flap, then at her hands. An idea, slow and deliberate, seemed to form behind those familiar eyes.

She stood up and approached the door itself. Her hand fumbled for the handle. My heart hammered against my tiny ribcage. *No. No, no, no.* If she figured out the door, my body would be outside, unsupervised, with the mind of a creature that considered the neighbour’s prize-winning roses the finest of litter boxes.

"Stop!" I screeched, a desperate, piercing sound. I launched myself at my own ankle, sinking my tiny teeth into the soft flesh of my Achilles tendon. It was a bizarre act of self-mutilation born of sheer desperation.

The Tenant yelped—a very human sound—and hopped on one foot, looking down at me with a mixture of shock and betrayal. "Bad kitty!" she scolded, in my voice. The absurdity was breathtaking.

But the distraction had worked. She forgot about the door handle, her attention now fully on me. She bent down, her movements still ungainly, and reached for me. I braced for a swat, but instead, her hand—my hand—was surprisingly gentle. She scooped me up, her grip uncertain but not unkind. She held me at eye level, our faces inches apart.

For a long moment, she just looked at me. Her expression was unreadable, a mask of my own features. Then, something shifted. The annoyance in her eyes softened into something else. Resignation? A flicker of… understanding? She brought me closer, until my forehead was pressed against hers. A low, resonant purr started up in my own chest, a vibration I felt through my entire being.

A wave of dizziness washed over me. The world swam, the scents and sounds blurring into a nauseating cacophony. I felt a terrible, wrenching sensation, like being turned inside out. I was falling.

I landed with a soft thud on the kitchen rug. I was on my hands and knees. Human hands. Human knees. I looked up. Sitting primly a few feet away was Mittens, calmly washing a paw with an air of profound boredom, as if the morning had been entirely uneventful. She glanced at me, blinked slowly, and then trotted over to her water-filled food bowl, sniffing it with disdain before walking away.

I stayed on the floor for a long time, my human mind struggling to process what had happened. The phrase "Not again" echoed in my memory. It hadn’t been a complaint about the situation, I realized. It had been a statement of weary routine. This was a game she played, a switch she could make. And for a reason I may never understand, she had decided, for now, to switch back.

I stood up, my body feeling strangely heavy and loud after the graceful silence of the cat. I looked at Mittens, who was now sunning herself in a patch of light on the floor. There was a new depth in her gaze, a secret knowledge we now shared. The world was a much stranger, and far more interesting, place than I had ever imagined. And I had a sinking feeling that this was only the first time *for me*.

samples.prompt: You're possessed by a demon who says they just need help hiding in your body until the hunt for him blows over.
samples.output:
It began not with a scream, but with a sigh. A deep, resonant exhalation that wasn’t my own, vibrating through my bones like a cello string. I was in the middle of chopping an onion, the knife poised in my hand, when the world tilted. Not literally, but the internal landscape of my mind, the quiet, solitary country I had inhabited for thirty-two years, suddenly had a squatter.

*Don’t panic,* a voice murmured. It wasn’t in the room. It was *behind* my thoughts, a bass note thrumming beneath the melody of my own consciousness. *It’s just me. Azazel. And before you ask, no, this isn’t about your soul. It’s a strictly temporary sublet.*

The knife clattered onto the cutting board. I gripped the counter, my knuckles white. “What?” I whispered, the word thin and reedy in the silent kitchen.

*A housing issue,* the voice continued, smooth as oiled silk. *There’s been a bit of a… misunderstanding Upstairs. A clerical error that’s been misinterpreted as a celestial insurrection. Long story short, there’s a hunt on, and your particular brand of benign anonymity makes for an excellent safe house. I just need to lie low for a century or two. Tops.*

This was insanity. A psychotic break brought on by stress, loneliness, and too much cheap coffee. I was having a conversation with a hallucination named Azazel who sounded less like a harbinger of the apocalypse and more like a harried businessman trying to book a last-minute hotel room.

“You’re a demon,” I managed, stating the obvious as if to anchor myself in reality.

*A demon is such a loaded term,* Azazel replied, a hint of pique in his mental tone. *I prefer ‘non-aligned spiritual entity.’ We’re not all fire and brimstone, you know. Some of us are more interested in… administrative critiques. Which, incidentally, is what got me into this mess. I filed a complaint about the inefficiency of the damnation process. The paperwork is a nightmare. Apparently, that constitutes ‘fomenting discord.’*

I slid down to the kitchen floor, my back against the cabinets. The cool linoleum was a tangible reality against my legs. This was not a dream. The voice was too clear, too present. It wasn’t shouting or demanding; it was negotiating.

*Look,* Azazel said, his tone softening into something almost placating. *I know this is an imposition. But I can make it worth your while. Consider it a symbiotic relationship. I need a host; you get a… well, let’s call it an upgrade.*

“An upgrade?” I croaked. My life was a study in muted tones. I was a freelance copyeditor, for God’s sake. My biggest thrill was finding a consistent typo in a manuscript. The idea of an “upgrade” was both terrifying and, I hated to admit, intriguing.

*Minor things,* he assured me. *A nudge here and there. That lingering sinus infection? Gone.* And as he said it, the dull pressure behind my eyes that had been my companion for a week simply vanished. The constant post-nasal drip dried up. I took a deep, clear breath. It was the first truly unobstructed breath I could remember in ages.

*See?* Azazel said gently. *No fuss, no glowing eyes or spinning heads. I’m not here to take the wheel. I’m just a very discreet passenger who’s happy to help with minor maintenance.*

And so began the strangest cohabitation imaginable. The first few days were a constant, low-grade terror. Every time Azazel spoke, I jumped. But he was true to his word. He didn’t try to control me. He was a whisper in the back of my mind, a silent observer who only commented when spoken to, or when he saw an opportunity for one of his “upgrades.”

He fixed the chronic ache in my lower back that three physiotherapists had failed to resolve. He didn’t just silence it; he explained it. *The problem isn’t the muscle, it’s a slight misalignment of the sacroiliac joint. Just shift your weight like this when you stand up.* I did, and there was a soft, satisfying pop. The pain melted away.

He became a bizarre kind of life coach. When I was struggling to find the right word in an edit, he’d offer a suggestion. Not a demonic one, but a startlingly apt one. *‘Pernicious’ is closer to what you’re looking for than ‘harmful,’* he’d murmur. He had an encyclopedic knowledge of grammar and style, honed, he claimed, from centuries of scrutinizing contractual fine print in infernal bargains.

Once, walking home late at night, I took a shortcut down an alley. Two figures emerged from the shadows, their intentions clear. My heart hammered against my ribs. Before I could even form a thought of panic, a strange calm settled over me. It wasn’t my calm. It was ancient and cold.

*Don’t run,* Azazel instructed, his voice dropping to a sub-vocal growl that resonated in my chest. *Look at the one on the left. Not at his eyes. Look at the space between his eyes. Now, smile. Not a friendly smile. Show him your teeth. Think about the void. Think about the cold between stars.*

I did as I was told. My lips pulled back into a rictus that felt alien on my face. I focused my gaze, pouring all the borrowed ancientness, all the implicit threat of a being that had witnessed the birth of galaxies, into that one spot. The man on the left stopped dead. He grabbed his friend’s arm, muttering something, and they both backed away, disappearing into the darkness faster than they had appeared.

*Predators recognize a bigger predator,* Azazel said calmly, the growl receding from my voice. *Sometimes, the best weapon is a suggestion.*

I leaned against the brick wall, trembling not from fear, but from the adrenaline aftershock. “Thank you,” I breathed.

*Think nothing of it. Tenant’s responsibility to ensure the structural integrity of the property. That includes you.*

Weeks turned into months. Azazel was the ultimate roommate. He didn’t eat my food, didn’t leave the bathroom a mess, and was a fascinating, if unsettling, conversationalist. He spoke of history not as dates and events, but as currents of human desire and folly. He’d been in Rome when it fell, not as a conqueror, but as a spectator, lamenting the poor logistical planning. He’d seen the Renaissance, which he found “flashy but derivative.”

I began to realize the “hunt” he was hiding from was deadly serious. Occasionally, a strange sensation would prickle at the edge of my awareness—a feeling of being scanned, like a searchlight sweeping over a dark ocean. Azazel would fall utterly silent during these times, retreating so deep inside me that I felt utterly alone. The first time it happened, the silence was more terrifying than his voice had ever been. I realized I’d grown accustomed to his presence. I’d started to… enjoy it.

One evening, as I was reading on the couch, a wave of profound cold washed over me, so intense my teeth chattered. The air in the room grew heavy, and the light from the lamp seemed to dim. A sense of immense, disapproving presence filled the apartment, a feeling of being judged and found wanting.

*They’re close,* Azazel’s voice was a terrified thread, so faint I barely heard it. *The Purifiers. They can sense a resonance. I have to go deeper. Don’t speak. Don’t even think about me. Think about your book. Think about the goddamn price of tea in China. Be boring. Be utterly, profoundly human.*

I focused on the words on the page, but they were just squiggles. My mind was a screaming void. I thought about my grocery list. I thought about the drip in the kitchen faucet I’d been meaning to fix. I thought about the soul-crushing boredom of editing a poorly written manual on industrial safety standards. I poured every ounce of my mundane life into my thoughts, building a wall of sheer normality around the terrified entity hiding within me.

The cold intensified, and for a single, heart-stopping moment, I felt a gaze upon me that was not of this world. It was pure, unadulterated purpose, and it saw everything. It saw the dust on the shelves, the unwashed mug in the sink, the lonely man on the couch. It scanned the depths of my being, and it found nothing but the quiet desperation of a mortal life.

And then, it was gone. The weight lifted. The light returned to normal. The cold receded, leaving me shivering in its wake.

I sat there for a long time, not moving. The silence in my head was absolute.

“Azazel?” I finally whispered.

Nothing.

A panic, different from any I’d felt before, gripped me. It was the panic of abandonment. The demon who had invaded my life had become my secret, my confidant, my protector. And now he was gone, and the silence was deafening.

*…that was too close,* his voice finally seeped back into my mind, weak and trembling. *They passed right over us. Your boredom… it was a masterpiece. A perfect shield.*

Relief flooded through me so powerfully it brought tears to my eyes. “Don’t do that again,” I said, my voice thick.

*I told you,* he said, his strength slowly returning. *Just until the hunt blows over.*

I leaned back on the couch, staring at the ceiling. A century or two, he had said. I tried to imagine my life stretching out before me, decades of this strange partnership. And the terrifying, undeniable truth I had to confront, there in the quiet of my apartment, was that the idea didn’t frighten me anymore. The world outside was cold and lonely. But in here, in the shared space of my own body, I was no longer alone. I was a safe house for a fugitive from heaven, and for the first time in a long time, my life had a purpose, however bizarre. The hunt would have to go on without its prize. The demon was staying. And secretly, foolishly, I was glad.

samples.prompt: A new voting system is introduced to the US. You awake the day after election night to discover that by some freak error you were elected President.
samples.output:
The first sensation was not of triumph, but of a profound, bone-deep wrongness. It was the silence that did it. The morning after any major election, the air itself should be thick with noise—the distant chatter of news anchors, the hum of traffic redirected by victory or protest rallies, the phantom buzz of a phone overwhelmed by notifications. This morning, there was only the soft hum of the central air and the distant, indifferent chirp of a sparrow outside my bedroom window.

I fumbled for my phone, its screen a black mirror. Dead. Strange, I’d charged it before bed. Plugging it in, I padded to the kitchen, the cold linoleum a shock against my feet. The small television on the counter was usually my portal to the post-election circus. I pressed the power button. Nothing. The screen remained dark. A knot of anxiety, small and tight, began to form in my stomach.

It was the knock on the door that shattered the illusion of a normal day. Not the friendly rap of a neighbor, but a firm, authoritative *thump-thump-thump* that spoke of polished shoes and serious business. Peering through the peephole, my heart performed a frantic, stumbling rhythm. Two figures stood on my modest porch, which was suddenly dwarfed by their presence. One was a severe-looking woman in a sharp pantsuit, the other a broad-shouldered man whose earpiece and stoic expression screamed Secret Service.

I opened the door a crack. “Can I help you?”

“Sir,” the woman said, her voice devoid of warmth. “I’m Cynthia Reed, from the General Services Administration. We need to speak with you urgently.” She held up a government ID, but my eyes were drawn past her to the black SUVs idling at my curb, their windows tinted to an opaque sheen.

“About what?” I managed, my voice embarrassingly thin.

“About the transition, sir. The election.”

I laughed, a short, nervous burst. “There must be a mistake. I think you have the wrong address. I voted, but I’m not… I mean, my name wasn’t on any ballot.”

“The system, sir,” she said, stepping forward in a way that was not quite an invitation to enter, but left me no choice but to step back. “The new ranked-choice, blockchain-verified, AI-optimized system. There was an… anomaly.”

The story, as Cynthia Reed explained it over a cup of tea she did not drink, was so absurd it bypassed comedy and landed squarely in nightmare territory. The new voting system, hailed as the ultimate in democratic transparency, was supposed to be foolproof. Voters ranked their choices, the blockchain recorded them immutably, and an AI tallied the results with flawless logic. The flaw, it turned out, was not in the logic, but in the input. A catastrophic data corruption event, a digital hurricane, had scrambled the voter rolls with the candidate database. The algorithm, designed to find the candidate with the broadest consensus, had scoured the chaos and pinpointed a single, unifying figure who appeared on virtually no one’s ballot, but who, through a series of insane digital cross-references and corrupted data points, was deemed the “least objectionable” choice.

That choice was me. A graphic designer from suburban Ohio. My sole political experience was a vehement, but ultimately losing, campaign for treasurer of my homeowners’ association, a campaign I had waged on a platform of more frequent mulch renewal for the common areas.

“The electoral vote count is certified,” Cynthia said flatly. “The system is, by law, final and unappealable. The anomaly is being treated as an act of God. You, sir, are the President-elect.”

The next few hours were a blur of disorienting rituals. The stoic agent, whose name was Agent Miller, began a perimeter sweep of my two-bedroom house, his professionalism unable to completely mask his bemusement at the overgrown petunias and the slightly lopsided bird feeder. My phone, once charged, exploded with a cacophony of alerts—thousands of texts, emails, and missed calls from numbers I didn’t recognize, from area codes like 202 and 212. I didn’t answer any. I just stared at the CNN headline on the screen: “GLITCH OR GODSEND? AMERICA’S ACCIDENTAL PRESIDENT.”

My family was sequestered somewhere safe, I was told. The world was watching. There were already protests in the streets—not for or against me, but for or against the machine that had created me.
